Group-level whole-brain task contrasts of joint action (leading/following) with social interaction between participant and experimenter measure social processing.

The task involves joint motor interaction but does not measure affiliation/attachment (no cooperation/attachment contrasts or loved-one vs stranger manipulations); missing AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2.
The analysis does not target classic social communication constructs (faces, explicit communicative signals); missing SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I1 and SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I2.
This conjunction (leading+following > rest) indexes sensorimotor joint action rather than explicit self-related judgment or agency contrasts; missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2.

The shared sensorimotor network does not specifically isolate perception/understanding of others (e.g., ToM, biological motion) in this conjunction; missing PERCEPTION_OTHERS_I1 and PERCEPTION_OTHERS_I2.
Table/contrast summarizing whole-group and subgroup Leading vs Following contrasts from a joint social interaction task meets global and local social processing criteria.

Contrasts summarize leading vs following but do not operationalize affiliation/attachment constructs (no cooperation/attachment contrasts); missing AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2.

While the contrasts involve interpersonal interaction, they do not specifically measure canonical social communication constructs (faces, gaze, explicit communicative signals); missing SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I1 and SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I2.

The Leading vs Following contrasts index role-specific motor and social processes rather than explicit self-judgment or agency measures as required by PERCEPTION_SELF_I1/I2. Missing inclusion criteria not met: GLOBAL_I1.
The contrasts include Following>Leading results and subgroup analyses that recruit mentalizing/other-perception regions (PCC, TPJ, pSTS), meeting perception-of-others criteria.
Whole-group Leading>Following contrast during an interpersonal joint-action task meets global and social processing inclusion criteria.
Leading>Following contrast reflects motor/control and role expertise rather than affiliation/attachment constructs; missing AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2.

The contrast targets role-specific motor and planning networks, not explicit social communication measures (faces, gaze, communicative signals); missing SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I1 and SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I2.

Although leading involves self-initiation, this contrast is not an explicit self/agency task as defined by PERCEPTION_SELF_I1/I2; the required self-judgment/agency manipulation is absent. Missing inclusion criteria not met: GLOBAL_I1.
Leading>Following activations reflect motor/control rather than perception/understanding of others (ToM/biological motion); missing PERCEPTION_OTHERS_I1 and PERCEPTION_OTHERS_I2.
Whole-group Following>Leading (deactivations label notwithstanding) contrasts arise from an interpersonal joint-action task and meet global/local social processing criteria.

The contrast highlights follower-related mentalizing/sensory networks but does not operationalize affiliation/attachment per AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1/I2. Missing inclusion criteria not met: AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1.

Although the contrast implicates social-cognitive regions, it does not target canonical social communication tasks (faces, explicit communication signals); missing SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I1 and SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I2.

The Following>Leading contrast indexes processing related to others (mentalizing, sensory tracking) rather than explicit self-focused judgments or agency manipulations required by PERCEPTION_SELF_I1/I2. Missing inclusion criteria not met: GLOBAL_I1.
Following>Leading activations engage classic other-perception/mentalizing regions (PCC, TPJ, pSTS), satisfying criteria for perception/understanding of others.
Followers-only Following>Leading contrast from a group-level whole-brain task map reflects social interaction and meets social processing criteria.

Although follower analyses recruit social-cognitive regions, the task does not operationalize affiliation/attachment measures (no cooperation/attachment contrasts); missing AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2.

The followers-only contrast emphasizes mentalizing and sensory tracking rather than explicit social communication constructs (faces/gaze/communicative signal reception/production); missing SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I1 and SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I2.

The followers-only contrast indexes others' actions and mentalizing rather than explicit self-knowledge/agency measures required by PERCEPTION_SELF_I1/I2. Missing inclusion criteria not met: GLOBAL_I1.
Followers-only Following>Leading activations include PCC, TPJ, pSTS and other mentalizing/biological-motion regions, meeting perception-of-others criteria.
Whole-group regression of Leading>Following with leader-skill covariate examines role expertise during interpersonal joint action and meets social processing criteria.
The regression probes motor/expertise correlates rather than affiliation/attachment constructs; missing AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2.
Leader-skill regression highlights premotor/motor regions and does not target canonical social communication measures (faces/gaze/etc.); missing SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I1 and SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I2.

Although leader-skill relates to self-initiated motor planning, this regression is not an explicit self-judgment or agency manipulation per PERCEPTION_SELF_I1/I2. Missing inclusion criteria not met: GLOBAL_I1.
Leader-skill correlated activations are in motor/improvisation networks, not in canonical other-perception/mentalizing regions; missing PERCEPTION_OTHERS_I1 and PERCEPTION_OTHERS_I2.
Whole-group regression (deactivation correlated with leader skill) is a group-level whole-brain task-evoked map from an interpersonal joint-action paradigm and meets social processing criteria.
This analysis addresses expertise-related activation/deactivation rather than affiliation/attachment constructs; missing AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2.
The deactivation/regression analysis targets expertise effects in motor/social networks, not explicit social communication measures; missing SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I1 and SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I2.
Although related to role expertise, this analysis does not constitute a self-focused judgment or agency manipulation required by PERCEPTION_SELF_I1/I2. Missing inclusion criteria not met: GLOBAL_I1.
No clear engagement of canonical other-perception/mentalizing regions in the leader-skill deactivation regression; missing PERCEPTION_OTHERS_I1 and PERCEPTION_OTHERS_I2.
Whole-group regression of Leading>Following with follower-skill covariate examines expertise in an interpersonal joint-action task and meets social processing criteria.

The follower-skill regression probes mentalizing/other-perception correlates rather than affiliation/attachment as defined by AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1/I2. Missing inclusion criteria not met: AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1.

Although follower-skill regression implicates social-cognitive areas, it does not target canonical social communication tasks (faces, gaze, explicit communicative exchanges); missing SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I1 and SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I2.
The regression indexes others-focused processing (mentalizing) rather than explicit self-judgment or agency contrasts required by PERCEPTION_SELF_I1/I2. Missing inclusion criteria not met: GLOBAL_I1.
Follower-skill covariation identifies PCC, TPJ, pSTS, mPFC—core regions for perceiving/understanding others—meeting the perception-of-others inclusion criteria.

Group-level whole-brain task fMRI in healthy adults using an Empathic Accuracy Task measuring social cognition and empathy; meets global and local inclusion criteria.
Task does not measure affiliation/attachment (no kinship, cooperation, loved-one vs stranger contrasts). Missing AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2.
Empathic Accuracy Task involves perception and interpretation of others' emotional expressions in videos (receptive social communication); group-level whole-brain map in healthy adults.
Analysis focuses on perceiving others' emotions rather than self-related judgments or self>other contrasts. Missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2.
Directly measures perception and understanding of others' emotional states (empathy/EA); group-level whole-brain task contrast in healthy adults.
Group-level whole-brain task fMRI contrast (neutral > emotional) derived from the Empathic Accuracy Task; still measures social/emotion processing within the social task.
Contrast does not assess affiliation/attachment constructs (no relevant task manipulation). Missing AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2.
Contrast is from a task that measures social communication (perception of emotional expressions in video) and is a whole-brain group-level map in healthy adults.
Contrast reflects processing of others' videos rather than self-related processes. Missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2.

Derived from an empathy task assessing perception/understanding of others' emotional states (even if showing greater activity for neutral), and is a whole-brain group-level analysis in healthy adults.
Modulation of BOLD by intra-individual empathic accuracy is a social-cognitive measure from a whole-brain group-level fMRI analysis in healthy adults.
Analysis examines empathic accuracy, not affiliation/attachment processes or contrasts. Missing AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2.
Empathic accuracy modulation reflects processing of social communicative signals (video emotion tracking); analysis is whole-brain and group-level in healthy adults.
Focus is on tracking others' emotional states (EA), not on self-related judgments. Missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2.
Directly assesses neural correlates of perceiving and understanding others' emotions (empirical modulation by EA) from a group whole-brain map in healthy adults.
Correlation of BOLD with participants' time-varying ratings of targets' emotional intensity is a social task measure (empathy/emotional tracking) from a whole-brain group analysis in healthy adults.
Analysis measures moment-to-moment emotion tracking, not affiliation/attachment constructs. Missing AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2.
Time-series correlation with perceived emotional intensity reflects reception of social communication (emotion in videos); whole-brain, group-level in healthy adults.
Analysis indexes perception of others' emotions rather than self-related processing. Missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2.
Measures neural correlates of perceiving and tracking others' emotional intensity over time (empathy/ToM-related), whole-brain group-level analysis in healthy adults.
Same as analysis_3: whole-brain correlation with participants' ratings of targets' emotional intensity in a social empathy task with healthy adults.
Does not assess affiliation/attachment constructs or contrasts. Missing AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2.
Derived from a task capturing reception of emotional signals in videos (social communication); whole-brain group-level analysis in healthy adults.
Focuses on tracking others' emotions, not self-related processing. Missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2.
Directly measures perception/understanding of others' emotional states via time-series correlations; whole-brain group-level map in healthy adults.

Global criteria are met: the NeuroSynth reverse-inference map is a group-level, whole-brain meta-analytic map derived from healthy adult studies. Local criteria are met: the analysis explicitly identifies brain regions associated with the term 'social' and thus measures social processing.

The analysis does not specifically target affiliation or attachment processes (e.g., kinship, cooperation/competition) and thus does not meet AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 or AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2. Missing inclusion criteria not met: AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1.

The NeuroSynth 'social' meta-analysis is broad and not specific to social communication tasks (e.g., face viewing, gaze). It does not meet SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I1 or SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I2. Missing inclusion criteria not met: GLOBAL_I1.
The analysis does not specifically assess self-related processing (e.g., self-judgment, viewing self) and therefore fails to meet PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2.

Although the map reflects social content broadly, it does not specifically target perception/understanding of others (e.g., ToM, empathy tasks) and thus does not meet PERCEPTION_OTHERS_I1 or PERCEPTION_OTHERS_I2. Missing inclusion criteria not met: GLOBAL_I1.

Group-level whole-brain contrast of partnered > non-partnered movements directly probes social interaction and social processing (mentalizing, somatosensation, reward).
Partnered interaction (including mutual interaction) engages social reward and cooperative bonding (nucleus accumbens, amygdala reported), satisfying affiliation/attachment constructs.
The partnered tasks rely on haptic exchange of movement cues (interpersonal communication), meeting social communication criteria.
This contrast addresses partnered versus solo movement and social processing rather than self-specific judgments or agency contrasts; missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2.
Partnered > non-partnered activates pSTS, TPJ and other regions involved in perception/understanding of others and dynamic social stimuli.
Parietal portion of the partnered>non-partnered contrast reflects social interaction and joint action processing.
Parietal activations are part of the partnered network that includes mutual/cooperative interaction and associated reward; thus relevant to affiliation/attachment.
Parietal activations (e.g., SPL, aIPL) support sensorimotor mapping for interpersonal haptic communication; meets social communication criteria.
This parietal contrast indexes partnered sensorimotor processing rather than explicit self-judgment or agency contrasts; missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2.
Parietal activations participate in perceiving and integrating others’ movements (action perception), meeting perception_of_others criteria.
Temporal regions in the partnered>non-partnered contrast (pSTS/STG) index processing of dynamic social stimuli and joint action.
Temporal-region results are part of the partnered network that includes mutual/reward-related responses and cooperative interaction, relevant to affiliation constructs.
pSTS/STG activations reflect perception of biological motion and haptic social signals—core features of social communication.
Temporal partnered activations concern perception of partner signals rather than self-specific judgments; missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2.
Temporal activations in pSTS/STG index action perception and understanding of others’ movements, fulfilling perception_others criteria.
Subcortical nodes reported in the partnered>non-partnered contrast (thalamus, nucleus accumbens) are part of social processing in haptic joint action.
Subcortical contrast shows reward-related nuclei (nucleus accumbens, amygdala reported elsewhere) in partnered interactions, directly relevant to affiliation/attachment.
Subcortical regions modulate social reward and valuation that support interpersonal communication dynamics in partnered action.
Subcortical partnered activations index reward/sensory processing rather than explicit self-judgment or agency contrasts; missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2.
Subcortical activations occur in the context of perceiving/responding to partner actions and social reward, consistent with perception/understanding of others.
Cerebellar activations reported for partnering contribute to sensorimotor coordination in joint social action and are part of the social processing contrast.
Although cerebellum is primarily motoric, it is reported as part of the partnered network that includes mutual/reward components; counted here under affiliation-related partnered processing.
Cerebellar contributions to coordination support haptic social communication during partnered movement.
Cerebellar partnered activity indexes coordination rather than explicit self-judgment or agency contrasts; missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2.
Cerebellar activations serve perception/action coupling in response to partners’ actions, fitting perception_others constructs (action perception).
Frontal role-specific activations (Leading, Following, Mutual) reflect social interaction processes across roles and are from whole-brain contrasts.

This frontal table primarily reports role-specific motor and cognitive activations rather than measures targeting affiliation/attachment; missing AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2.
Frontal regions (IFG, medial frontal areas) are implicated in sequencing, signalling and interactive exchange—consistent with social communication via haptic cues.
Frontal activations include areas involved in self-initiation, motor planning and agency (e.g., IFG, medial frontal areas) consistent with perception/understanding of self (agency).
Frontal role contrasts also index processes for mapping self/other and integrating partner information (aIPL/IFG interactions), meeting perception_others criteria.
Parcellated specific-activations table representing role contrasts contributes to understanding social interaction and joint action.
This table emphasizes role-specific sensorimotor and sequencing effects rather than explicit affiliation measures; missing AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2.
Role-specific activations reflect the exchange and mapping of haptic signals and therefore meet social communication criteria.
Role-specific activations include motor planning/self-initiation components (leading) that relate to agency and self-processing.
These role contrasts include areas (pSTS, aIPL) implicated in perceiving and understanding others’ actions.
Whole-brain table presenting role-specific activations for social joint action; meets social processing inclusion.
This table focuses on role-specific neural activations (motor/sensory) rather than dedicated affiliation/attachment contrasts; missing AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1.
Findings reflect interpersonal signalling and haptic communication across roles; thus satisfy social communication criteria.
Role-specific contrasts include leading-related self-initiation and monitoring processes (agency), consistent with perception_self.
Role contrasts also highlight areas for action perception and mentalizing (pSTS, TPJ) relevant to perception of others.
Cerebellar components of role contrasts contribute to joint-action processing and are part of the social processing results.
Cerebellar tables reflect coordination and motor processing rather than explicit affiliation/attachment measures; missing AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1.
Cerebellar coordination supports interpersonal exchange of haptic signals during social communication in joint action.
Cerebellar involvement in self-initiated bimanual coordination is relevant to agency/self-perception aspects of the task.
Cerebellar activity supports prediction and coupling to partner movements, aligning with perception_others (action perception).
Frontal-specific role activations reflect social interaction processes; whole-brain group-level evidence present.
Frontal role-specific table emphasizes motor/planning differences between roles rather than explicit affiliation/attachment contrasts; missing AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1.
Frontal activations (IFG/medial frontal) are implicated in signalling and sequencing during interaction, consistent with social communication.
Frontal activations include self-initiation and monitoring systems (agency), meeting perception_self criteria.
Frontal role contrasts also index processes for understanding and integrating partner actions (perception of others).
Parietal role-specific results contribute to the social interaction network and meet whole-brain criteria.
Parietal role tables emphasize spatial/motor planning differences between roles rather than explicit affiliation/attachment measures; missing AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1.
Parietal activations (SPL/aIPL) subserve interpersonal mapping and sensorimotor communication during joint action.
Parietal areas (SPL) are implicated in spatial aspects of self-initiated movement and agency, fitting perception_self criteria.
Parietal role contrasts support action perception and integration of partner cues, consistent with perception_others.
Temporal role-specific results reflect processing of partner-derived dynamic cues (pSTS/STG) and are part of social processing contrasts.
This temporal-specific table emphasizes motion/social perception rather than explicit affiliation/attachment measures; missing AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1.
Temporal (pSTS/STG/MT+) activations directly index perception of biological/social motion and haptic communication, meeting social communication criteria.
Temporal role activations pertain to perceiving partners’ motion rather than explicit self-related judgments; missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2.
Temporal activations reflect action/animacy perception and mentalizing about others, consistent with perception_others criteria.
Subcortical role-specific activations capture reward/valuation differences across roles, contributing to social processing in joint action.
Subcortical table reports nucleus accumbens and related reward circuitry that were elevated during the mutual condition, directly indexing social reward/affiliation.
Subcortical structures modulate reward and motivational aspects that underpin cooperative social communication in joint action.
Subcortical role-specific activations focus on reward/valuation rather than explicit self-judgments or agency contrasts; missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2.
Subcortical activity appears in the context of responding to partner actions and social outcomes (valuation of others’ actions), consistent with perception_others.
Frontal role-specific table (duplicate region partition) supports social processing in joint action.
This frontal partition reports motor/cognitive role differences rather than explicit affiliation/attachment contrasts; missing AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1.
Frontal areas contribute to signaling and coordination during haptic interaction, consistent with social communication.
Frontal activations relate to self-initiation, motor planning and agency (perception_self), especially for Leading.
Frontal role contrasts also implicate integration of partner info and action-mapping (perception of others).
Parietal partition of role-specific activations contributes to joint-action social processing.
Parietal partition emphasizes sensorimotor planning differences rather than explicit affiliation/attachment measures; missing AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1.
Parietal regions support interpersonal sensorimotor mapping and thus social communication during joint action.
Parietal activations reflect spatial planning and agency-related processes tied to self-initiated movement (perception_self).
Parietal role contrasts involve integration of partner information for action perception, meeting perception_others criteria.
Temporal partition of role-specific activations indexes social motion perception and so is part of social processing.
Temporal partition focuses on perception/sequencing and not direct affiliation/attachment contrasts; missing AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1.
Temporal activations (pSTS/MT+) reflect reception of dynamic social signals and haptic motion communication, consistent with social communication.
Temporal role-specific activations pertain more to perceiving partners than to explicit self-judgments or agency contrasts; missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2.
Temporal activations index action perception and understanding of others’ movements (perception_others).
Subcortical partition of role-specific activations (e.g., reward nuclei) contributes to social processing in joint interaction.
This subcortical table reports nucleus accumbens/other reward structures more engaged during Mutual, directly relevant to affiliation/attachment constructs.
Subcortical activity modulates the motivational/reward aspects of interpersonal exchange and supports social communication dynamics.
Subcortical role-specific activations emphasize reward/valuation rather than explicit self-judgments or agency contrasts; missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2.
Subcortical activations occur in the context of evaluating partner interactions and social outcomes (perception/valuation of others’ actions), consistent with perception_others.
Improvisation contrasts were run within the social interaction paradigm (Leading and Solo vs Mutual and Alone) and relate to social processing in joint contexts.
The improvisation contrasts focus on motor-planning and working-memory rather than explicit measures of affiliation/attachment; missing AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2.

The analysis is a whole-brain, group-level contrast of ISC during viewing of a social/moral movie (kinship manipulation), directly assessing social processing across subjects.
The contrast tests effects of perceived kinship (genetic vs non-genetic sisters) — a kinship/affiliation manipulation — and therefore measures affiliation/attachment-related processing.

Global criteria are met but the analysis does not target social communication constructs (e.g., face/gaze/explicit communication reception or production). Missing required local inclusion criteria. Missing inclusion criteria not met: GLOBAL_I1.

Global criteria are met but the analysis does not measure self-related processing (no self > other or self-judgment contrast). Missing required local inclusion criteria PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2.

The analysis contrasts conditions that modulate activity in regions associated with theory-of-mind/understanding others (VMPFC, TPJ/STS, precuneus etc.), and thus measures perception/understanding of others.
Whole-brain group contrast from the same social/moral movie comparing perceived kinship conditions; it indexes social processing (even if the reverse contrast highlights occipital areas).
The contrast is part of the kinship manipulation (genetic vs non-genetic sisters) and thus is on a task measuring affiliation/attachment, even if the observed effect is greater in visual cortex.

Although the stimulus contains dialogue and social exchange, this specific analysis/contrast does not target social-communication constructs per the local inclusion examples (faces/gaze/emotion recognition). Missing SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I1 and SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I2.
The contrast does not measure self-related processing (no self-judgment or self > other contrast). Missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2.

This specific contrast (non-genetic > genetic) highlights occipital/visual regions and does not reflect measures of theory-of-mind/empathy/understanding others as required. Missing PERCEPTION_OTHERS_I1 and PERCEPTION_OTHERS_I2 for this contrast.

The GLM contrasts decision vs non-decision in a moral task involving choices about sister/friend/strangers — a group-level whole-brain map indexing social processing and moral decision-making about social others.
The moral decision task explicitly involves choosing between kin (sister), friend, and strangers — a direct affiliation/attachment measure (loved one vs stranger comparisons).

The GLM decision contrast indexes moral decision-making / social valuation rather than core social-communication processes (faces/gaze/explicit communicative reception/production). Missing SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I1 and SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I2.
The decision vs non-decision contrast does not target self-related judgments or self > other processing. Missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2.

The moral decision GLM recruits regions implicated in understanding others and ToM (VMPFC, TPJ, precuneus, etc.) while subjects decide about others (sister, friend, strangers), satisfying perception/understanding of others criteria.

Contrast SocAdj > PhyConf is a canonical social (ToM) vs non-social contrast from a whole-brain group analysis in healthy adults and thus directly measures social processing.
The REMICS contrasts do not target affiliation/attachment constructs (e.g., kinship, loved-one vs stranger). Missing AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2.
The task/contrast does not measure social communication constructs such as face or gaze processing. Missing SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I1 and SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I2.
The analysis does not assess self-related processes (self-judgment or self vs other). Missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2.
SocAdj > PhyConf probes Theory-of-Mind / understanding others (social mental state inference) in a whole-brain group contrast in healthy adults.
The Soc > Phy (Time-point 1) contrast compares social versus physical scenarios at the group whole-brain level in healthy adults and indexes social processing engaged by the social scenarios.
This contrast does not measure affiliation/attachment constructs (no kinship/cooperation or loved-one vs stranger manipulation). Missing AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2.
Contrast is not a social communication task (no faces/gaze/emotion perception manipulation). Missing SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I1 and SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I2.
No self-related judgment or self vs other manipulation is present in this contrast. Missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2.
Soc > Phy at Time-point 1 isolates processes involved in representing others' mental states (ToM) in a whole-brain healthy adult group contrast.
The Soc > Phy (Time-point 2) contrast is a whole-brain group comparison of social versus physical scenarios during T2 and clearly indexes social processing (ToM-related activation).
No affiliation/attachment manipulation is present in this contrast (no kinship/cooperation or loved-one comparisons). Missing AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2.
This contrast does not target social communication (faces/gaze/emotion) processes. Missing SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I1 and SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I2.
No self-related processing (self-judgment, viewing self) is assessed by this contrast. Missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2.
Soc > Phy (Time-point 2) isolates neural activity related to understanding others' mental states (ToM) in a whole-brain healthy adult group analysis.

Adj > Conf (Type of context) is a whole-brain group contrast probing contextual adjustment processes; although it pools social and physical trials, it recruits ToM-related regions and therefore falls under broad social processing in this task context.

The context adjustment contrast does not measure affiliation/attachment constructs (no cooperation/kinship or loved-one manipulations). Missing AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2.
Adj > Conf does not target social communication (faces/gaze/expression) processes. Missing SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I1 and SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I2.
This contrast does not assess self-related judgments or self vs other processing. Missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2.

Adj > Conf pools social and physical trials and the effect was largely domain-general (contextual updating) rather than specific to perceiving/understanding others; therefore it does not meet PERCEPTION_OTHERS_I2 (contrast does not specifically index understanding others). Missing inclusion criteria not met: GLOBAL_I1.

The analysis is a group-level, whole-brain task contrast involving self-evaluation and endorsement of others' evaluation (social-related tasks). It measures social processing (self- and others-related trait judgments).
The task does not specifically measure affiliation/attachment (e.g., kinship, cooperation/competition, social bonding) — AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2 are not met.
The task does not target social communication constructs like face/voice processing or communicative behaviors — SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I1 and SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I2 are not met.
The analysis includes self-evaluation contrasts (self-judgment of trait adjectives), which directly measure perception/understanding of the self.
The analysis also includes endorsement-of-others' evaluation conditions (contrasts involving others' evaluations of the participant), which measure perception/representation of others' evaluations.

The contrast is agentic self-evaluation (self-judgment), directly meeting Perception/Self criteria.
This contrast involves only self-evaluation (SA vs Fixation) and does not measure perception/understanding of others; PERCEPTION_OTHERS_I1 and PERCEPTION_OTHERS_I2 are not met.

Global criteria met (healthy adult sample, whole-brain group-level voxelwise contrast). The contrast Social-Reg > Social-Look isolates socially-induced emotion regulation, a social-related task that measures social processing.

The contrast does not directly manipulate or compare affiliation/attachment conditions (e.g., loved one vs stranger). Although attachment scores were correlated post-hoc, the analysis itself is not a task measuring affiliation/attachment (missing AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2).

The contrast is not a social-communication task (e.g., face processing, gaze, or communicative production/reception). It measures social regulation, not social-communication per se (missing SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I1 and SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I2).
The contrast does not index self-perception or self-judgment contrasts (no Self > Other or explicit self-evaluation manipulation). Missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2.

Global criteria met. The Social-Reg > Social-Look contrast engages regions associated with representing others' mental states (TPJ, precuneus, dorsomedial PFC) and isolates processes involving understanding the psychotherapist's intentions; therefore it measures perception/understanding of others.
Global criteria met. This conjunction includes Social-Reg (a social task) and thus reflects social processing common to Social- and Self-Reg.
The conjunction identifies common regulation areas but does not specifically measure affiliation/attachment behaviors or contrasts (missing AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2).
The analysis does not index social-communication-specific processes (e.g., face/gaze/expressive communication). Missing SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I1 and SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I2.
Although Self-Reg is involved, this conjunction is not an explicit self-perception/self-judgment contrast (missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2).

Global criteria met. The conjunction includes Social-Reg components and common regions include areas implicated in understanding others (e.g., TPJ/precuneus/dmPFC), indicating perception/understanding of others is measured.
Global criteria met. This contrast isolates areas distinctively recruited by Social-Reg (vs Self-Reg) and therefore targets social-related processing.

The contrast identifies Social-Reg-specific regions but does not explicitly manipulate affiliation/attachment conditions; it is not a task contrast of affiliation/attachment (missing AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2).

Although Social-Reg recruits social-cognitive regions, the task is not a social-communication paradigm (faces/gaze/expressive communication) as required by SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I1/I2. Missing inclusion criteria not met: GLOBAL_I1.
The contrast targets social-cognitive (other-oriented) processes rather than explicit self-perception or self-judgment contrasts (missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2).

Global criteria met. Distinct Social-Reg areas include TPJ, dorsomedial PFC, and precuneus—regions central to representing others' mental states—so the contrast measures perception/understanding of others.

This contrast isolates regions preferentially involved in Self-Reg (self-induced reappraisal) and does not reflect a social-related task; missing SOCIAL_PROCESSING_ALL_I1 and SOCIAL_PROCESSING_ALL_I2.
The Self-Reg distinct contrast does not measure affiliation/attachment; missing AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2.
This contrast is not a social-communication task or contrast (missing SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I1 and SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I2).
Although Self-Reg involves self-initiated regulation, the contrast is not an explicit self-perception/self-judgment manipulation (no Self > Other); missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2.
The Self-Reg distinct contrast does not target perception/understanding of others (missing PERCEPTION_OTHERS_I1 and PERCEPTION_OTHERS_I2).

Global criteria are met (healthy adult sample, group-level whole-brain SPM analysis). The contrast isolates increased social interaction (ball-toss high-frequency > normal-frequency, contrasted with button-press), which clearly measures social processing related to affiliation and reward.

Global criteria are met. The task explicitly manipulates frequency of social interaction (Cyberball inclusion), measuring affiliation/attachment-related processes (need to belong, social reward). The contrast targets affiliation/attachment (high-frequency social inclusion).

Although the task involves interaction, it does not target social communication constructs (e.g., face processing, emotion recognition, gaze/expressive exchanges). Missing required local inclusion criteria: SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I1 and SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I2.

The analysis was not designed as an explicit self-processing/task (e.g., self-judgment, viewing the self, or Self>Other contrasts). While the precuneus activation is interpreted as related to self-image, the contrast does not meet the explicit criteria. Missing required local inclusion criteria: PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2.

The task does not explicitly measure perception/understanding of others' mental states (e.g., Theory of Mind, empathy, compassion). Missing required local inclusion criteria: PERCEPTION_OTHERS_I1 and PERCEPTION_OTHERS_I2.

Contrast 'Meaning > Physical' explicitly manipulates a social-related interpretive attitude and evokes canonical social-cognition areas (mPFC, TPJ, IFG). Global criteria met and the contrast measures social processing.

Contrast does not target affiliation/attachment processes (no cooperation/competition or kinship/loved-one vs stranger manipulation). Missing inclusion criteria AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2.
Task is about extracting meaning from objects rather than measuring social communication (e.g., face/gaze/emotion/gesture perception). Missing SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I1 and SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I2.
The contrast is not a self-specific (Self>Other) contrast or explicit self-judgment; it addresses meaning vs physical properties. Missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2.
The contrast does not explicitly probe perception/understanding of others' mental states (e.g., ToM/empathy). Missing PERCEPTION_OTHERS_I1 and PERCEPTION_OTHERS_I2.
Physical > Meaning contrasts object-related perceptual/motor processing (fusiform, precentral), not social processing. Missing SOCIAL_PROCESSING_ALL_I1 and SOCIAL_PROCESSING_ALL_I2.
This contrast measures physical/perceptual features, not affiliation/attachment. Missing AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2.
This is a physical-feature contrast (object perception/manipulation), not social communication. Missing SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I1 and SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I2.
Not a self-related contrast; it probes physical properties rather than self-judgment or self vs other. Missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2.
Not assessing perception/understanding of others (no ToM/empathy manipulation). Missing PERCEPTION_OTHERS_I1 and PERCEPTION_OTHERS_I2.
The 'Own > Other' contrast within the meaning task probes self-related social-cognitive processing and activates social cognition regions (mPFC, TPJ), meeting social processing criteria.

Contrast compares own versus others' models but does not explicitly test affiliation/attachment (no cooperation vs competition or kinship/loved-one manipulations). Missing AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2.
Although social-cognitive, the contrast is not a social communication task (not faces/gaze/emotion/gesture focused). Missing SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I1 and SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I2.
This is a Self > Other contrast for stimuli tied to participants' own creations; it probes self-related perception/agency and meets the Perception/Self criteria.
The contrast is focused on self > other rather than probing perception/understanding of others' mental states per se. Missing PERCEPTION_OTHERS_I1 and PERCEPTION_OTHERS_I2.

The interaction (Own>Other × Collective>Individual) targets socially relevant processing (collective social history modulating self-related responses) and activates social-emotional and social-cognition regions (ACC, insula, IFG).

The interaction isolates effects of collective (vs individual) construction and relates activity (insula) to self-reported relatedness to group members, directly probing affiliation/attachment processes.

This interaction addresses collective self-related and social-emotional effects rather than social communication per se (faces/gaze/gesture); missing SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I1 and SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I2.
The interaction includes Own>Other (self-related) effects specific to collective models, implicating self-related perception/agency processes (precuneus/ACC/insula).

Although the contrast includes an Own vs Other component, the interaction is oriented to self-related responses to collective history and social affiliation rather than explicit probing of others' mental states; missing PERCEPTION_OTHERS_I1 and PERCEPTION_OTHERS_I2.

EE>EN directly probes processing of verbally communicated emotional empathy (auditory social communication).
EE>EN does not involve self-judgment or explicit self-processing contrasts (missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1/I2).

Contrast targets empathic vs unempathic processing but not affiliation/attachment-specific tasks or contrasts (does not meet AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1/I2). Missing inclusion criteria not met: AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1.

EE+CE>baseline contrasts processing of communicated empathic comments versus neutral baseline — meets social communication criteria.

Contrasts empathic comments against baseline and recruits mentalizing/social-cognitive regions — meets perception-of-others criteria.
EE>baseline is a whole-brain contrast assessing processing of emotional empathic comments — a social processing measure.

No self-related task components or contrasts; missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1/I2.

Averted gaze incongruent > averted gaze congruent probes gaze-following/attention under averted-eye context — a social processing contrast; whole-brain healthy adult data.
Contrast is about gaze congruency within averted-gaze context, not affiliation/attachment. Missing AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1/I2.
Contrast examines communicative aspects of gaze cues (incongruent vs congruent) in observed averted-gaze context — meets social communication criteria; whole-brain healthy adult contrast.
No self-related processing or self>other contrasts present; missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1/I2.
Contrast requires interpreting others' gaze/attention and differences in processing others' cues — satisfies perception-of-others inclusion criteria with whole-brain healthy adult data.

Global criteria met (healthy adult sample, group-level whole-brain task contrasts). The SAMT is a social-affective task manipulating emotion and group membership and the contrast (Incongruent > Congruent) indexes regulation of mimicry in a social context, thus measuring social processing.

Although the contrast measures generalized mimicry regulation, it is not specific to affiliation/attachment (it pools across emotions and groups). Does not meet the local inclusion requirement for an affiliation/attachment-specific contrast. Missing inclusion criteria not met: AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1.

Global criteria met. The task presents faces (emotional expressions and group cues) and hand movements; the incongruent>congruent contrast captures imitative processing in the presence of facial stimuli, fitting social communication (reception/processing of facial and action cues).

Global criteria met. The incongruent>congruent contrast is the canonical mimicry-regulation contrast and is interpreted (and shows rTPJ activation) as engaging self–other distinction/agency processes, consistent with perception/understanding of self (agency subcomponent).

Global criteria met. The task requires perception and interpretation of others' facial expressions and group membership while responding to observed actions, fitting perception/understanding of others.

Global criteria met. This contrast isolates mimicry regulation specifically for happy (affiliative) faces vs angry, directly measuring social-affective processing and regulation of mimicry in a social context.

Global criteria met. The contrast targets mimicry regulation specifically for happy faces (an affiliative signal); the study explicitly interprets this as reciprocation of affiliation, so it measures affiliation/attachment-related processing.
Global criteria met. The contrast examines responses to facial emotional expressions (happy) and imitative hand movements, which fit social communication reception/production constructs.
Global criteria met. The Happy-specific mimicry regulation contrast recruited rTPJ and is interpreted as engaging self–other distinction (agency), consistent with perception/understanding of self.
Global criteria met. The contrast involves perceiving others' affiliative emotional states (happy faces) and how that modulates action perception/mimicry, fitting perception/understanding of others.
Global criteria met. This contrast isolates mimicry regulation for angry faces; it still probes social-affective processing (perception of emotion) and its effect on mimicry.

This contrast targets angry (non-affiliative) facial stimuli and is not measuring affiliation/attachment (positive social-bond processes). Does not meet AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1/I2. Missing inclusion criteria not met: AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1.
Global criteria met. The contrast involves viewing emotional face stimuli (angry) and imitative actions, which fall under social communication reception and its modulation of action processing.

The Angry-specific contrast did not engage the self–other distinction network (rTPJ) in the reported results and is focused on non-affiliative affect; therefore it does not clearly meet the Perception/Self (agency/self-judgment) inclusion criteria (PERCEPTION_SELF_I1/I2). Missing inclusion criteria not met: GLOBAL_I1.
Global criteria met. The contrast isolates responses to others' angry expressions and how these influence mimicry regulation, directly addressing perception/understanding of others' emotional states.
Global criteria met. This contrast isolates mimicry regulation specifically for out-group faces vs in-group and thus measures social processing related to group membership and social-affective cues.

Global criteria met. The authors interpret increased mimicry to out-group faces as an affiliative appeasement response; the contrast targets group-based affiliative regulation and thus meets affiliation/attachment criteria.
Global criteria met. The contrast involves perceiving group cues (faces) and hand movements and evaluates communicative/imitative processes in a social-interaction context.

This contrast primarily engaged AI/MCC and vPMC/IPL networks related to salience, threat processing, and motor resonance rather than self–other distinction/agency. Does not meet PERCEPTION_SELF_I1/I2. Missing inclusion criteria not met: GLOBAL_I1.
Global criteria met. The contrast targets processing of others' group membership and inferred threat/affiliative intent, directly addressing perception/understanding of others.
Global criteria met. This contrast isolates mimicry regulation specific to in-group faces (in-group > out-group), capturing social-affective processing relevant to affiliation and group dynamics.
Global criteria met. In-group-specific mimicry effects relate to affirmation of group bonds and positive social affiliation; this contrast measures affiliation/attachment-related processing.
Global criteria met. The contrast examines responses to in-group faces and imitative behavior, addressing social communication (face and action processing) components.

The in-group-specific contrast did not emphasize self–other distinction processes in the reported results (no clear rTPJ/self-agency activation); thus it does not meet PERCEPTION_SELF_I1/I2. Missing inclusion criteria not met: GLOBAL_I1.
Global criteria met. The contrast isolates processing of others' group membership (in-group), relevant to perception/understanding of others and social cognition about group members.

The why>how contrasts specifically probe understanding and inference about others' mental states (theory-of-mind/mental-state attribution) in emotional expressions and actions; global criteria satisfied.

This contrast isolates regions showing stronger why>how responses for social than nonsocial stimuli (social attribution), meeting global whole-brain and healthy-sample criteria and targeting social processing.

Contrast focuses on social attribution and mental-state inference, not affiliation/attachment constructs (no kinship/relationship/cooperation contrasts). Missing AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2.

The social>nonsocial why>how contrast emphasizes processing of emotional expressions and intentional actions (interpreting others' emotions/intentions), which maps onto receptive social communication; global criteria met.
Contrast targets understanding of others' mental states rather than self-related judgments or self>other contrasts. Missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2.

This analysis explicitly isolates regions more engaged when attributing mental states to others (emotions and actions) than for nonsocial scenes; meets global whole-brain and healthy-sample criteria and local perception-of-others criteria.

Viewing and labeling facial emotions is a Social Communication task (reception of facial communication) at the group whole-brain level in healthy adults.
The contrasts concern perception of others' facial emotions, not self-related judgments or viewing one's own face (missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2).
The analyses probe representations of others' emotional states (labeling others' facial expressions) in a healthy adult whole-brain group design.
Group-level whole-brain regression maps linking alexithymia to responses during facial emotion labeling assess social processing (how individuals process others' emotions).
The analysis examines emotion labeling and alexithymia, not affiliation/attachment constructs (missing AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2).
This regression identifies neural correlates of facial emotion reception/labeling (social communication reception) at the whole-brain group level in healthy adults.
The analysis concerns perception of others' emotions and associations with alexithymia, not self-referential judgments (missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2).
Regression maps reflect neural processing of others' emotional states (perception/understanding of others) in healthy adults.
Group-level whole-brain regression maps linking alexithymia to responses during facial emotion labeling assess social processing (how individuals process others' emotions).
The analysis examines emotion labeling and alexithymia, not affiliation/attachment constructs (missing AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2).
This regression identifies neural correlates of facial emotion reception/labeling (social communication reception) at the whole-brain group level in healthy adults.
The analysis concerns perception of others' emotions and associations with alexithymia, not self-referential judgments (missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2).
Regression maps reflect neural processing of others' emotional states (perception/understanding of others) in healthy adults.
Group-level whole-brain regression of TAS-20-DDF with angry>neutral contrasts probes social processing involved in labeling others' emotions.
The analysis targets emotion recognition and alexithymia, not affiliation/attachment behaviour or relationships (missing AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2).
Contrast (angry>neutral) and its correlation with TAS-20-DDF reflects reception of facial communication (emotion recognition) in healthy adults at whole-brain level.
This analysis concerns processing of others' facial emotions, not self-judgment or viewing one's own face (missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2).
Angry>neutral contrasts correlated with alexithymia index others' emotional state processing and therefore meet perception-of-others criteria at whole-brain group level.
Group-level whole-brain regression of TSIA-DDF with emotional face contrasts assesses social processing (representation and labeling of others' emotions).
The analysis concerns emotion labeling and alexithymia, not affiliation/attachment constructs (missing AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2).
TSIA-DDF correlations with face-evoked activity reflect reception/processing of facial communication, meeting social communication criteria.
This analysis examines others' facial emotion processing linked to alexithymia, not self-related processing (missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2).
TSIA-DDF correlations with emotional face contrasts index perception and understanding of others' emotional states in a healthy whole-brain group design.
Group-level whole-brain regression maps linking TSIA-DDF to face labeling contrasts assess social processing of others' emotions.
This analysis targets emotion recognition and alexithymia rather than affiliation/attachment processes (missing AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2).
TSIA-DDF correlations with face-evoked activity reflect reception/processing of facial communication (emotion labeling) in healthy adults.
These contrasts involve perception of others' emotions, not self-related tasks (missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2).
TSIA-DDF correlations with emotional face contrasts index perception/understanding of others' emotional states in a whole-brain group analysis of healthy adults.

Global criteria met (healthy adult sample, group-level whole-brain task-evoked contrast). The task is social (viewing campaign videos depicting social interactions and victims) and the CV>NV contrast measures social processing (STS activation and correlation with empathic expression).

The analysis does not assess affiliation or attachment constructs (no measures of close relationships, kinship, cooperation/competition or contrasts like Loved one vs Stranger). Missing required local inclusion criteria AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2.

The analysis does not specifically measure social communication subcomponents (e.g., facial communication reception/production, gaze or mimicry contrasts). Missing required local inclusion criteria SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I1 and SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I2.
The task does not involve self-perception/self-judgment contrasts (e.g., Self > Other, viewing pictures of self). Missing required local inclusion criteria PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2.

Global criteria met and the task directly assesses perception/understanding of others via empathy-related measures and theory-of-mind related processing; the CV>NV contrast and correlations with empathic expression index satisfy the construct.

Group whole-brain conjunction of triad, self, and other (healthy adults) assesses social processing across tasks; meets global and local social-processing criteria.
The analysis does not measure affiliation/attachment constructs (no cooperation/attachment or loved-one vs stranger contrasts); missing AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2.
The conjunction is not a social-communication task (no face/gaze/gesture or communication-specific contrasts); missing SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I1 and SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I2.
Conjunction includes the self task (self-judgments) at the group whole-brain level in healthy adults and thus reflects self-related processing.
Conjunction includes the other (other-referential/Theory-of-Mind) task and thus indexes processing of others' mental states in a whole-brain group map of healthy adults.
Triad > (self & other) is a whole-brain group contrast in healthy adults that isolates social triadic interaction processing; meets global and local social-processing criteria.

Contrast isolates triadic interaction but does not test affiliation/attachment (no cooperation/attachment or loved-one vs stranger comparisons); missing AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2.
Contrast does not measure social communication (no faces, gaze, or communicative exchange contrasts); missing SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I1 and SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I2.

This contrast isolates triadic (interaction) processing versus self and other and does not measure self-referential processing specifically; missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2 for this contrast.

Triad trials require imagining an interaction with another person (mentalizing/action understanding about another), so the triad-specific contrast indexes processing of others' actions/intentions in a whole-brain group map.
Self > (other & triad) is a whole-brain group contrast in healthy adults isolating self-referential processing; it is a social-related facet (self) and meets social-processing criteria.

Contrast isolates self-referential processing but does not measure affiliation/attachment (no cooperation/attachment or loved-one vs stranger comparisons); missing AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2.
Self > (other & triad) does not assess social communication (no faces/gaze/gesture communication measures); missing SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I1 and SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I2.
This contrast explicitly isolates self-referential judgments (self > others & triad) in a whole-brain group analysis of healthy adults, satisfying self-perception criteria.

This contrast specifically isolates self-related activity (self > other & triad) and therefore does not measure perception/understanding of others for this contrast; missing PERCEPTION_OTHERS_I1 and PERCEPTION_OTHERS_I2.
Other > (self & triad) is a whole-brain group contrast in healthy adults isolating other-referential/theory-of-mind processing and thus meets social-processing criteria.

Contrast isolates other-referential processing but does not test affiliation/attachment (no cooperation/attachment or loved-one vs stranger comparisons); missing AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2.
Other > (self & triad) does not assess social communication (no faces/gaze/gesture or communicative exchange measures); missing SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I1 and SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I2.
This contrast isolates other-referential processing (other > self & triad) and therefore does not measure self-perception for this contrast; missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2.
This contrast explicitly isolates other-referential/theory-of-mind processing (other > self & triad) in a whole-brain group analysis of healthy adults, meeting perception-of-others criteria.

Global criteria are met (healthy adult sample; group-level whole-brain task-evoked contrasts). The contrast (reactive–aggressive initial phase > neutral initial phase) is a social-related task that probes perception and interpretation of social interactions and emotions, thus measuring broad social processing.

The contrast compares reactive–aggressive versus neutral interactions and does not specifically measure affiliation or attachment processes (e.g., cooperation, kinship, loved-one vs stranger). Missing required inclusion criteria AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2.

Global criteria are met. The task involves viewing dynamic social interactions (body gestures, emotional signaling) and the contrast isolates neural processing of socially communicative cues (emotion/body-language), fitting Social Communication.

Although stimuli are first-person in perspective, the contrast is not a self-vs-other or self-judgment contrast and does not directly measure self-related processes defined by PERCEPTION_SELF_I1/I2. Missing required inclusion criteria PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2.

Global criteria are met. The contrast targets perception and understanding of others' actions and emotional states (empathic perceptual processing of aggressive vs neutral social interactions), satisfying Perception and Understanding of Others.

Global criteria are met (healthy adult sample; group-level whole-brain task-evoked contrast). The contrast reactive–aggressive > social-positive isolates social processing differences between two affective interaction types and therefore probes broad social processing.

The contrast is reactive–aggressive > social-positive and does not specifically measure affiliation/attachment (e.g., loved-one vs stranger or cooperation paradigms). Missing required inclusion criteria AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2.

Global criteria are met. The contrast compares two socially communicative conditions (aggressive vs social-positive) and isolates neural responses to communicative/social signals (emotion, body gestures), meeting Social Communication criteria.
This contrast does not operationalize self-specific processing (no self>other or self-judgment contrast). Missing required inclusion criteria PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2.

Global criteria are met. The contrast directly probes perception and understanding of others' emotional actions by comparing aggressive versus positive social interactions, consistent with Perception and Understanding of Others.

Whole-brain parametric contrast (feedback ratings, self>other) measuring social reward processing of trait feedback in healthy adults; therefore meets social processing criteria.

Does not meet PERCEPTION_OTHERS_I2: the reported contrast is Self>Other (indexes self-related activation) rather than a contrast that measures perception/understanding of others. Missing inclusion criteria not met: GLOBAL_I1.
Global criteria met. The Other>Self localizer contrast comes from a social cognitive task (trait judgments about another person) and thus measures social processing.
Does not meet AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1: the Other>Self localizer does not assess affiliation/attachment, cooperation, or competition. Missing inclusion criteria not met: AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1.

Does not meet SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I1/I2: the contrast reflects trait judgments about another person rather than a communication-specific task (faces, gaze, auditory communication, etc.). Missing inclusion criteria not met: GLOBAL_I1.

Does not meet PERCEPTION_SELF_I2: this is an Other>Self contrast and therefore does not index perception/understanding of the self (Self>Other required). Missing inclusion criteria not met: GLOBAL_I1.
Global criteria met and the Other>Self contrast specifically measures perception/understanding of another person (other-focused judgments), satisfying the perception-of-others criteria.
Global criteria met. The Communication>Moral whole-brain contrast examines social-content stimuli (remote communication items) and therefore indexes social processing.

Does not meet AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1: this contrast compares communication vs moral content and does not assess affiliation/attachment, cooperation, or competition. Missing inclusion criteria not met: AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1.
Global criteria met and the contrast isolates Communication-related stimuli (remote communication items), which fit the Social Communication construct (reception of non-facial communication).

Does not meet PERCEPTION_SELF_I2: the contrast is Communication> Moral (collapsing across self/other) and does not specifically isolate self-related processing (Self>Other required). Missing inclusion criteria not met: GLOBAL_I1.

Does not meet PERCEPTION_OTHERS_I2: the contrast isolates communication content rather than perception/understanding of others (Other-focused contrasts required). Missing inclusion criteria not met: GLOBAL_I1.
Global criteria met. The Moral>Communication contrast examines moral-behavior stimuli (socially relevant moral content), which is a form of social processing.

Does not meet AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1: the contrast compares content types (moral vs communication) and does not assess affiliation/attachment, cooperation, or competition. Missing inclusion criteria not met: AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1.

Does not meet SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I2: this contrast isolates moral > communication content, not a communication-focused contrast required for Social Communication. Missing inclusion criteria not met: GLOBAL_I1.

Does not meet PERCEPTION_SELF_I2: the contrast is Moral>Communication collapsing across self/other and does not isolate self-referential processing (Self>Other required). Missing inclusion criteria not met: GLOBAL_I1.
Does not meet PERCEPTION_OTHERS_I2: this contrast does not specifically measure perception/understanding of others (Other-focused contrasts required). Missing inclusion criteria not met: GLOBAL_I1.
Global criteria met. The Self>Other contrast (collapsing across moral/communication) is derived from a social task and indexes social processing related to self/other distinctions.

Does not meet AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1: although the overall experiment includes group competition, this specific contrast is Self>Other and does not directly measure affiliation/attachment or cooperation/competition. Missing inclusion criteria not met: AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1.

Does not meet SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I1/I2: the Self>Other contrast is self-referential in nature and not a communication-specific contrast (faces/gaze/auditory communication). Missing inclusion criteria not met: GLOBAL_I1.
Global criteria met and the Self>Other contrast directly indexes self-referential processing (perception/understanding of self).

Does not meet PERCEPTION_OTHERS_I2: the contrast is Self>Other (focus on self), not an Other>Self or other-focused contrast required to index perception/understanding of others. Missing inclusion criteria not met: GLOBAL_I1.
Global criteria met. The Other>Self contrast (collapsing across moral/communication) comes from a social task and therefore indexes social processing.

Does not meet AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1: this contrast is Other>Self and does not directly assess affiliation/attachment, cooperation, or competition. Missing inclusion criteria not met: AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1.

Does not meet SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I1/I2: the Other>Self contrast is not a communication-specific contrast (faces/gaze/auditory communication) and thus does not satisfy Social Communication criteria. Missing inclusion criteria not met: GLOBAL_I1.

Does not meet PERCEPTION_SELF_I2: this is an Other>Self contrast and therefore does not index perception/understanding of the self (Self>Other required). Missing inclusion criteria not met: GLOBAL_I1.
Global criteria met and the Other>Self contrast directly measures perception/understanding of others (other-focused judgments), satisfying perception-of-others criteria.

Group-level whole-brain GLM on healthy adults using social stimuli (bystander videos); the parametric contrast directly tests social influence (group size) on neural responses, meeting social-processing criteria.
The task/contrast does not target affiliation or attachment processes (AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2 not met).
The contrast does not specifically measure social communication (e.g., facial/expressive communication) — SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I1 and SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I2 not met.
This analysis does not measure self-related processes (PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2 not met).
The parametric effect of number of bystanders probes perception/understanding of others (effects of others' presence on observers' neural responses), meeting perception-of-others criteria.
The Control > bystander contrast primarily indexes visual complexity differences (control manipulation) rather than social-processing per se; SOCIAL_PROCESSING_ALL_I2 not met.
Contrast does not assess affiliation/attachment constructs (AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2 not met).
Contrast does not target social communication (faces/gaze/emotion recognition) — SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I1 and SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I2 not met.
Contrast does not involve self-related judgments or self-perception (PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2 not met).
Control > bystander isolates visual/complexity differences rather than perception/understanding of others (PERCEPTION_OTHERS_I2 not met).
Falling > standing contrasts witnessing an emergency versus a non-emergency using social stimuli; it captures social processing of others in need.
This contrast does not measure affiliation/attachment (AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2 not met).
Not specifically a social-communication task (no explicit measures of facial/gaze communication); SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I1 and SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I2 not met.
Contrast pertains to perception of another's state rather than self-related processing (PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2 not met).
Falling > standing indexes perception/understanding of another's distress (empathy/action perception), meeting perception-of-others criteria.
Standing > falling still contrasts social states of another person and reflects social stimulus processing (face/body recognition and social context), meeting social-processing criteria.
Contrast does not target affiliation/attachment constructs (AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2 not met).
Contrast is not a social-communication measure (no explicit communicative exchanges or facial/gaze reception tasks) — SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I1 and SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I2 not met.
This contrast concerns perception of another person rather than self-related processing (PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2 not met).
Standing > falling involves differential perception of another person's state (body/face processing), satisfying perception-of-others criteria.

No self-referential or self vs other contrasts in the fluency analyses; missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2.

This is a segment from the movement fluency/interaction table (group whole-brain results) and relates to social perception of kinematic effects; meets criteria.

This interaction examines contingency and kinematics, not affiliation or attachment constructs; missing AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2.
The interaction contrast assesses how communicative cues (contingency/kinematics) modulate perception of nonverbal exchanges—fits social communication criteria.
No self-oriented measures or contrasts in this interaction; missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2.
Interaction identifies regions sensitive to others' actions under combined contingency and kinematic contexts, consistent with perception-of-others construct.
This table segment contains the movement fluency and interaction results (group whole-brain contrasts) directly probing social perception; meets criteria.
Entries concern kinematics/interaction neural responses, not affiliation/attachment measurements; missing AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2.

No self-related contrasts or self-judgment tasks in these results; missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2.

Group whole-brain analyses of interns (healthy adults) tested neural responses during a social task about recommending messages; this directly measures social processing (mentalizing, reward, persuasion).
Analysis does not test affiliation/attachment constructs (e.g., kinship, close relationships, cooperation/competition); missing AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2.

The task concerns exchanging socially relevant information (interns preparing to recommend/persuade), and analyses index communicative outcomes (intentions, salesperson, buzz), meeting social communication criteria.
The intention effect showed MPFC and PC/PCC activations linked to self-relevance and self-related processing, so the analysis measures self-perception processes.
Analyses (buzz and salesperson effects) report TPJ and DMPFC activations consistent with theory-of-mind/understanding others, meeting perception-of-others criteria.
Salesperson effect is a whole-brain group analysis in healthy adults indexing brain activity related to persuasion and social-influencing ability — core social processing.
Salesperson effect targets mentalizing and persuasion, not affiliation/attachment constructs; missing AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2.
The salesperson effect indexes interns' success at communicating/persuading producers (production aspect of social communication), measured with whole-brain group analyses.
The salesperson effect was exclusively associated with bilateral TPJ (mentalizing) and did not report self-related midline activations; missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2.
Salesperson effect showed bilateral TPJ activity, directly mapping onto perception/understanding of others (theory-of-mind).
This whole-brain group analysis in healthy adults examines neural predictors of message propagation (mentalizing, reward, intentions), which are social-processing constructs.
Analysis focuses on persuasion/buzz and mentalizing rather than affiliation/attachment measures; missing AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2.
Analyses index processes that enable effective message transmission (intent to recommend, persuading others), consistent with social communication production and reception.
Intention-related activations (MPFC, PC/PCC) reported in the study reflect self-referential processing captured in these whole-brain analyses.
Buzz and salesperson effects reported DMPFC/TPJ involvement, consistent with perception/understanding of others (theory-of-mind) in whole-brain analyses.

Match > Unrequited compares social outcomes (both partner yes) and indexes social reward and interpersonal processing; meets global and local social processing criteria.
This contrast isolates rewarding matched social interaction (mutual yes) and relates to affiliative/attachment processes (desire for contact with matched partners).

Match > Unrequited targets reward/value differences for different partner types rather than explicit self-judgment or self-focused evaluation; missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2.

Rejection > Disinterest examines responses to social rejection vs non-rejection in a romantic/social task, meeting global and local social-processing criteria.
Rejection (no from a desired partner) directly indexes negative affiliative outcomes and attachment-related processes (social rejection), satisfying affiliation inclusion criteria.
Contrast involves processing socially communicative feedback (partner's decision) and affective response to that communication.
Although rejection impacts self-related affect, this contrast does not directly probe self-judgment or self-reflection constructs required by PERCEPTION_SELF_I1/I2; missing those inclusion criteria.

Rejection > Disinterest primarily indexes affective/painful response to being rejected rather than explicit inference about others' mental states; missing PERCEPTION_OTHERS_I1 and PERCEPTION_OTHERS_I2.

Contrast focuses on others' decisions and anticipated outcomes rather than explicit self-evaluation or self-judgment; missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2.
