This analysis reports the main effect of masked sad > neutral faces (emotion response) but does not test attachment/affiliation-related effects (no attachment-modulation contrast), so local inclusion criteria for Affiliation/Attachment are not met (no attachment-related measure applied in this specific contrast). Missing inclusion criteria not met: AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1.

Viewing emotional faces (sad > neutral) is a receptive facial communication task (affects reception of facial signals); this is a group-level whole-brain task-evoked map measuring social communication.
The contrast measures perception of others' facial emotions, not self-related judgments or self>other contrasts; missing required inclusion criteria PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2.
Masked emotional face perception indexes representations about others' emotional states (empathy/understanding of others) at the group level.
Group-level whole-brain analyses of masked happy > neutral faces measure social processing (face emotion perception).

This analysis reports the main effect of masked happy > neutral faces and does not test attachment/affiliation-related effects; local inclusion criteria for Affiliation/Attachment are not met for this specific contrast. Missing inclusion criteria not met: AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1.
Viewing emotional faces (happy > neutral) is a receptive facial communication task; the contrast captures social communication processing at the group level.
The contrast concerns perception of others' facial emotions rather than self-related processing; missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2.
Masked happy face responses index perception/understanding of others' emotional states and meet the perception-of-others criteria at the group whole-brain level.

This analysis is a group-level whole-brain regression linking attachment avoidance to brain responses to masked sad faces—directly addresses social processing (individual differences in social-affiliative signal processing).
This analysis explicitly tests brain activation correlations with attachment avoidance (RSQ) in response to social stimuli, directly measuring affiliation/attachment-related effects.
Analysis assesses modulation of facial emotion (reception) processing by attachment—meets social communication criteria (viewing faces; face-related contrasts).
Analysis concerns perception of others' emotional faces and individual differences in attachment, not self-related processing; missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2.
Regression of attachment avoidance on responses to others' facial emotions indexes perception/understanding of others (empathic/simulation processes) and meets local criteria.
Group-level whole-brain correlation of attachment avoidance with responses to masked happy faces addresses social processing (face emotion perception and attachment modulation).
This analysis directly tests relationships between attachment avoidance and brain responses to social/affiliative facial signals (happy faces), meeting affiliation/attachment criteria.
Analysis examines neural reception of facial communication (happy faces) as modulated by attachment—meets social communication criteria.
The analysis pertains to perception of others' emotional faces, not self-related judgments; missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2.
Correlation between attachment and responses to others' happy faces targets perception/understanding of others and satisfies perception-of-others criteria.
Same as analysis_3: whole-brain correlation of attachment with masked happy-face responses measures social processing.
This analysis explicitly links attachment avoidance to neural responses to affiliative signals (happy faces), meeting affiliation/attachment inclusion criteria.
Measures reception of facial communication (happy faces) and its modulation by attachment—meets social communication criteria.
Analysis focuses on others' facial emotions rather than self-related processes; missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2.
Attachment-related modulation of responses to others' emotional faces indexes perception/understanding of others and satisfies the local criteria.

Group-level whole-brain task contrasts of viewing eyes/pupils in healthy adults measure social processing broadly (perception of social cues and their affective significance).
Task does not measure affiliation or attachment constructs (missing AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2).
Viewing eye stimuli (faces/eyes) and related contrasts are canonical social communication tasks (reception of facial communication).
Task does not probe self-related processes or self-judgment (missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2).
Viewing and evaluating others' eye/pupillary signals indexes perception and understanding of others' internal states (empathy/social inference).
Whole-brain group contrast of change in observed/observer pupil size in healthy adults indexes social processing of autonomic signals between individuals.
Contrast does not assess affiliation/attachment constructs (missing AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2).
Analyses examine perception of dynamic facial/eye cues (pupil changes), which falls under reception of facial communication.
Analysis does not probe self-awareness or self-judgment processes (missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2).
The contrast evaluates how observed others' pupillary signals (and coherence with observer) are processed, meeting perception-of-others criteria.
Interaction (negative > positive) of feedback coherence in healthy adults probes social processing (salience of incongruent social/autonomic cues).
Contrast contrasts feedback coherence and does not operationalize affiliation/attachment (missing AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2).
The interaction examines differential processing of eye/pupil cues (receptive facial communication), fitting social communication criteria.
This interaction does not measure self-related judgments or self-referential processing (missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2).
Negative>positive feedback interaction highlights processing of another's divergent autonomic signals—consistent with perception/understanding of others' states.
Interaction (positive > negative) examines processing of coherent pupillary signals in a social context, fitting broad social processing.
Contrast does not target affiliation/attachment constructs (missing AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2).
Positive>negative feedback examines response to observed eye/pupil cues (receptive facial communication), meeting social communication criteria.
No measures of self-judgment or self-referential processes are present (missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2).
Contrast evaluates processing of others' pupillary cues (coherent responses), consistent with perception/understanding of others.

Group-level whole-brain contrasts of listening to footsteps (one vs two walkers, and vs noise/rest) probe social processing (perception of others, group dynamics); global and local inclusion criteria met.
Task does not measure affiliation/attachment (no kinship, bonding, cooperation or loved-one vs stranger contrasts); missing AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2.
The contrasts involve auditory social cues (footsteps) and compare them to noise/rest, meeting criteria for social communication (reception of non-facial auditory social signals).
The task does not probe self-related processing or self > other judgments; missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2.
Contrasts probe perception and understanding of others (animacy/action perception, mentalizing about two walkers), satisfying perception-of-others criteria.

Task explicitly contrasts observation of social versus individual actions and the role of gaze; this is a group-level whole-brain task contrast probing social processing.

Task involves observing and inferring others' interactions and intentions (triadic relations, mental-state inference), matching Perception/Understanding of Others.

Group-level whole-brain task contrast in healthy adults manipulating social approach (happy vs angry) directly measures social processing (perception of social cues, intentions, dominance/affiliation).
Task explicitly manipulates affiliative vs threatening social signals (happy = affiliative, angry = low affiliation). The contrast assesses neural responses related to affiliation/attachment signals.
Stimuli involve reception of facial communication (dynamic facial expressions, eye contact); contrast measures neural response to facial/social communication.
Does not assess self-related processing (no self-judgment or self vs other contrast). Missing required inclusion criteria PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2.
Task measures perception and understanding of others (interpreting others' emotions, intentions, action/biological motion), so the contrast addresses perception-of-others constructs.

Stimuli involve reception of facial communication (dynamic facial expressions, eye contact); contrast measures neural response to facial/social communication.

Stories are social-rule Wason tasks (social contracts, precautions, descriptives). Contrast Stories>Rest captures task-evoked social reasoning and meets global whole-brain group-level criteria.

Contrast is collapsed across content and is not specifically a measure of affiliation/attachment (e.g., kinship, cooperation-focused comparisons). Missing AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and/or AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2.
Task does not probe social communication constructs like face/eye-gaze or expressive/receptive communication. Missing SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I1 and SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I2.
Tasks involve reasoning about others/ rules, not self-judgment or self-related processing. Missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2.
Story reading includes interpretation phases that engage theory-of-mind/understanding-others processes (social contract stories evoke ToM areas). Contrast meets whole-brain group-level criteria.

This is the inverse contrast (Rest>Stories); it does not directly measure task-evoked social processing. Missing SOCIAL_PROCESSING_ALL_I2 (analysis does not capture social-task activation in the expected direction).
Not a contrast measuring affiliation/attachment. Missing AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2.
Does not measure social communication constructs. Missing SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I1 and SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I2.
Does not measure self-related processing. Missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2.
Inverse contrast (Rest>Stories) does not index perception/understanding of others in the task-positive direction. Missing PERCEPTION_OTHERS_I2.
Cards>Rest captures the task decision phase of Wason problems (cards shown for social rule violation detection) and is a task-evoked, whole-brain group map involving social-rule decisions.

Card responses are collapsed across content and not specifically measuring affiliation/attachment (no cooperation vs non-cooperation contrast). Missing AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2.
Task does not target social communication (faces/gaze/emotion) reception or production. Missing SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I1 and SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I2.
Card decision phase is not a self-related processing task. Missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2.

Card contrasts (collapsed across content) mainly engage executive/decision networks (DLPFC, parietal) and did not robustly activate ToM/perception-of-others areas in this study. Missing PERCEPTION_OTHERS_I2 (contrast does not index others' mental-state reasoning specifically).
Inverse contrast (Rest>Cards) does not directly index task-evoked social processing in the task-positive direction. Missing SOCIAL_PROCESSING_ALL_I2.
Not a contrast measuring affiliation/attachment. Missing AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2.
Does not measure social communication constructs. Missing SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I1 and SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I2.
Does not measure self-related processing. Missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2.
Inverse contrast does not index perception/understanding of others in the task-positive direction. Missing PERCEPTION_OTHERS_I2.
Contrast isolates social-exchange (social contract) versus precautionary reasoning — a social-related cooperative/interactional task; whole-brain group-level map.
Social contract tasks probe cooperative social exchange and cheater detection (cooperation/competition), matching affiliation/attachment constructs (example: cooperation).
Contrast does not involve facial/expressive or receptive communication stimuli (faces, gaze, emotional expressions). Missing SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I1 and SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I2.
Contrast examines reasoning about others' intentions/cheating, not self-related judgments. Missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2.
Social contract interpretation explicitly requires inferring others' desires/goals (ToM); contrast shows activation in anterior/posterior temporal ToM regions. Meets perception-of-others criteria.
Contrast isolates social-exchange (social contract) > descriptive rules; measures social-rule inference specific to social exchange. Whole-brain group-level map.
Social contract stimuli probe cooperation/social exchange (cheater detection), consistent with affiliation/attachment/cooperation constructs.
Does not target communicative signal processing (faces, gaze, auditory social cues). Missing SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I1 and SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I2.
Contrast concerns interpreting others' intentions/benefits, not self-related judgments. Missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2.
Social contract interpretation engages ToM (inferring desires/goals); this contrast isolates that process and meets perception-of-others criteria.

This table/note pertains to the social contract contrasts and the reported activations for social-exchange reasoning; it is part of the whole-brain social-task results and thus reflects social processing.
Associated with social contract results (cooperation/cheater detection), matching affiliation/attachment constructs (cooperation).
Note/table metadata does not represent a social-communication-specific contrast (faces/gaze/emotional cues). Missing SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I1 and SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I2.
Content concerns others' mental states and social exchange rather than self-related processing. Missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2.
The note documents whole-brain activations for social contract contrasts that engage ToM/perception-of-others regions; therefore it reflects perception-of-others processing.
Precautionary reasoning contrasts are social-rule tasks (concern about people in danger) and thus are within the broader social processing domain; whole-brain group-level map.
Precaution contrasts probe hazard management/danger detection rather than cooperation/attachment; missing AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2.
Task does not target communicative signal processing (faces/gaze/etc.). Missing SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I1 and SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I2.
Precautionary reasoning concerns danger/hazard assessments of others' actions, not self-judgment. Missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2.

Although precautionary tasks involve social scenarios, the study reports that precaution interpretation did not engage ToM areas; the contrast (precautions>social contracts) does not index perception-of-others (mental-state inference) specifically. Missing PERCEPTION_OTHERS_I2.
Precautions>Descriptives isolates precautionary social-rule reasoning (hazard management) — still a social-related task and a whole-brain group map.
Precaution tasks focus on hazard/danger assessment rather than affiliation/cooperation; missing AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2.
Does not probe communicative signal processing. Missing SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I1 and SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I2.
Not a self-related contrast. Missing PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2.
Precautionary interpretation did not differentially engage ToM/perception-of-others processes in this study; contrast does not index understanding others' mental states. Missing PERCEPTION_OTHERS_I2.
Duplicate precaution>social contract contrast — precautionary reasoning is a social-rule task (hazard-focused) and reflected in whole-brain activations.
Contrast probes hazard/danger processing rather than cooperation/attachment. Missing AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2.
Does not involve facial/communicative stimuli or communication reception/production constructs. Missing SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I1 and SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I2.

SOC×OTHER specifically indexes processing of social signals directed to others (third-person perspective / perception of others) in a whole-brain group contrast—meets perception-of-others criteria.

This is a whole-brain group-level task contrast in healthy adults viewing faces (pre- vs post-surgery). The task involves perceiving social stimuli (faces) and the contrast probes social processing (responses to disfigured vs non-disfigured faces), so both global and local inclusion criteria are met.

The task does not measure affiliation or attachment (no kinship, close-relationship, cooperation, or loved-one vs stranger contrasts). Missing required local inclusion criteria: AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I1 and AFFILIATION_ATTACHMENT_I2.

Participants viewed photographs of faces in a gender-judgement task and the whole-brain contrast compares face types (pre vs post surgery). Viewing faces maps onto reception of facial communication; thus global and local inclusion criteria are satisfied.
The task does not involve self-related judgments or viewing the self; it targets perception of other faces. Missing required local inclusion criteria: PERCEPTION_SELF_I1 and PERCEPTION_SELF_I2.

Although results are interpreted in terms of empathy/mentalizing, the task was a gender-judgement on other people’s faces and did not explicitly measure empathy, theory of mind, or other standard perception-of-others tasks. Missing required local inclusion criteria: PERCEPTION_OTHERS_I1 and PERCEPTION_OTHERS_I2.

Global criteria met (healthy adult sample, whole-brain group-level task-evoked contrast). The contrast examines recall of relationship episodes (self and other), a clearly social task assessing social processing (self/other-referencing, interpersonal memory).

Global criteria met and the task specifically probes formative interpersonal/relationship episodes and references attachment theory/internal working models; thus it measures affiliation/attachment-related processes.

Although the paradigm uses pictorial cues, it does not primarily measure social communication (e.g., face or emotion recognition, gaze, or communicative behavior). Missing local inclusion criteria: SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I1, SOCIAL_COMMUNICATION_I2.
Global criteria met and the contrast self-relevant > control explicitly measures self-referential processing (recalling one’s own relationship episodes), matching perception/understanding of self.
Global criteria met and the contrast other > control explicitly measures perception/understanding of others (recalling observed relationship episodes involving others), matching the construct.
